& dbo_pdo::describe ( $  tableName  ) 

try to reduce the fields of given table to the basic types bool, unixdate, int, string, float, date, enum

example:

Array ( [table] => test [primary] => Array [identity]=> a [cols] => Array ( [a] => Array ( [default] => CURRENT_TIMESTAMP [null] => [key] => 'PRI' [length] => 0 [type] => date )

[g] => Array ( [default] => [null] => [key] => 'UNI' [length] => 0 [type] => unsupported:time ) )

)

Parameters:
string $tableName name of the table to analyze
Returns:
unknown

Definition at line 256 of file dbo_pdo.php.

& dbo_pdo::query ( $  s,
$  idnames = false,
$  fields = false 
)

execute query and return useful data depending on query-type

SELECT / SHOW => resultset array REPLACE / UPDATE / DELETE / ALTER => affected rows (int) INSERT => last insert id (int) RENAME / LOCK / UNLOCK / TRUNCATE /SET / CREATE / DROP => Returns if the operation was successfull (boolean)

Parameters:
string $s sql-statement
string $idname which field-value to use as the key of the returned array (false=dont care)
Returns:
array

Definition at line 472 of file dbo_pdo.php.

dbo_pdo::replace ( $  tableName,
$  fields,
$  pairs 
)

REPLACE works exactly like INSERT, except that if an old row in the table has the same value as a new row for a PRIMARY KEY or a UNIQUE index, the old row is deleted before the new row is inserted

Parameters:
string $tableName replace from this table
array $fields name=>value pairs of new values
string $pairs enquoted names to escaped pairs z.B.[name]='value'
Returns:
int modified rows.
